title: British Airways boss Willie Walsh says Heathrow third runway is too expensive
text:

Fri, Jul 31, 2015, 16:30 BST - UK Markets closed British Airways boss Willie Walsh says Heathrow third runway is too expensive By Sophie Jamieson | Telegraph – 5 hours ago 2.72 0.00 
International Airlines Group boss Willie Walsh says the cost of the third runway at Heathrow is 'outrageous'" as the company announces a 40pc rise in quarterly profits 
The boss of British Airways owner IAG has said the cost of an extra runway at Heathrow is "outrageous" and his company would not pay for it. 
A third runway at the West London airport was recommended by the Davis Commission at the beginning of July. 
But International Airlines Group chief executive Willie Walsh said he opposed the plans because of the expense. 
"We think the costs associated with the third runway are outrageous and certainly from an IAG point of view we will not be supporting it and we will not be paying for it," Mr Walsh said. 
Mr Walsh made the comments as IAG, which also owns Iberia and budget carrier Vueling, announced an 11pc rise in revenue to €5.67bn in the second quarter, pushing operating profits up 40pc to €530m. 
That left pre-tax profits for the six months to June 30 at €412m, nearly triple the amount reported this time last year. 
The company still expects full-year operating profit to be over €2.2bn. 
IAG boss Willie Walsh said the group had seen "very good results" (WARREN ALLOTT) 
IAG's €1.4bn takeover bid for Aer Lingus (Other OTC: AELGF - news ) looks set to be formally accepted by the middle of August, after a majority of shareholders voted in favour of the deal. 
On Friday IAG declared its offer for Aer Lingus unconditional and waived a 90pc acceptance condition after 62.48pc of Aer Lingus shareholders voted for the deal. Ryanair’s formal acceptance - which is widely expected - will take the vote above the 90pc threshold initially set by IAG. 
Ryanair and any other remaining shareholders now have until August 18 to vote on the deal, which was backed by Irish politicians in May. 
Speaking on Friday morning, Mr Walsh said he was confident that the deal with Aer Lingus would go ahead, following a commitment from Ryanair to sell its stake in the Irish carrier. 
“We have made a very fair offer for the company. We are excited about Aer Lingus joining IAG,” Mr Walsh said. 
He added that the strong quarterly and half-year results were partly thanks to cost cutting and improved productivity. 
“We said previously that profit improvement would be slower in the second quarter and we are on track to reach our full-year targets," he said. 
"We continue to take cost out of the business, with both employee and supplier unit costs down at constant currency, and improvements in productivity levels.”
